title-group.article-title: Accounting for the Effects of Identity on Political Behavior
title-group.subtitle: Descent, Strength of Attachment, and Preferences in the Regions of Spain

author-notes.corresp: Steven L. Burg, Brandeis University, Department of Politics, Mailstop 058, Waltham, MA 02454 Email:burg@brandeis.edu

fn.p: Lachen T. Chernyha holds a BA and MA in political science from Brandeis University and is currently a PhD student in the Political Science Department at Brown University. Her research focuses on ethnic identity and state institutions. She is preparing a dissertation on democratic state responses to regional autonomy and secessionst movements.

Steven L. Burg is Adlai E. Stevenson Professor of International Politics at Brandeis University. He is coauthor, with Paul Shoup, of The War in Bosnia Herzegovina: Ethnic Conflict and International Intervention (1999) and chairman of the Board of Directors of the Council on Inclusive Governance, an international NGO based in New York that advises governments on ethnic conflict mitigation through strategies of inclusion.

abstract.p: This article examines the determinants of identification within the autonomous communities (ACs) of Spain and explores whether “activated identities” guide behavior. The authors test this hypothesized effect empirically and demonstrate that regional and especially (non-Spanish) national activated identity affect preferences for exclusionary policies and for greater autonomy or independence for the AC. Both preferences and activated identities increase the likelihood of voting for regional, rather than statewide, political parties. The authors argue that the strength of attachment to identity (i.e., to the AC to or Spain) and the effect of identities on preferences constitute the mechanisms that link identity to behaviors. Thus, the authors contribute to, and help to clarify, both the theoretical and empirical literatures focused on the relationship between identity and behaviors.

body.p: This article explores whether Spanish data support the relationship theorized by Chandra and Wilkinson (2008) and by Abdelal, Herrera, Johnston, and McDermott (2009) that identity affects behavior. We examine variations in self-identification within selected autonomous communities (or regions, henceforth referred to as ACs) of Spain and test whether and how variations in these identities affect policy-relevant preferences and behaviors. We examine the relationship among identity, preferences concerning language use in the AC and concerning organization of the Spanish state, and voting for regional political parties in AC elections. We use identical surveys conducted in several of the ACs by the Centro de Investigaciones Sociológicos (CIS) in 1998 to explore the sources of identity and the effects of identity on preferences and on voting in the ACs. We test our findings using data from a 2005 CIS survey of all of Spain. The 1998 surveys record the characteristics of descent and culture of respondents in the three historically non-Castilian regions (Basque Country, Catalonia, and Galicia) and the culturally mixed region of Valencia. At least a portion of the population of each of these ACs speaks a non-Castilian vernacular language, and it is in these regions that identification with the AC, relative to identification with Spain, is the strongest. We use data from 2005 to test our findings concerning the relationship between identity and preferences and to explore the effects of identity and preferences on voting. Our analysis provides empirical evidence to support the relationship theorized by Chandra and Wilkinson, by Abdelal et al., and by others that identity affects the behaviors of individuals. Our findings are consistent with those of other scholars working on identity and voting in Spain and of scholars working on other ethno-regionally differentiated and devolved states, such as Belgium (Billiet, Maddens, & Frognier, 2006) and Canada (Mendelsohn, 2002), who find that differences in ethno-regional identification are associated with differences in orientations toward the common state.

Palleres (1991; Palleres, Montero, & Llera, 1997) has examined differences in the distributions of identity among those who report voting for “nonstatewide” (i.e., regionalist and nationalist) parties in AC elections in Spain. He demonstrates that stronger identification with the AC is more widespread among the supporters of nationalist and regionalist parties. His approach is largely descriptive and does not include analysis of the influence of identity relative to other factors on voting in AC elections. Palleres’s more recent study of voting in statewide (Spanish) elections does develop regression models for predicting votes for the major parties, but these do not include identity as a predictor (Palleres, Riba, & Fraile, 2007). J. R. Montero and Torcal (1990) and Llera (2009) also take a descriptive approach in their studies of identity and preferences in the ACs, as do the individual contributors to the comprehensive collection of analyses of electoral behavior in the regions published by CIS in 1998 (Alcántara & Martínez, 1998). The findings of these studies suggest the importance of understanding the implications of differences in self-identification and the degree of attachment to the common state for preferences concerning the organization of that state and for electoral behavior. The analysis presented here goes beyond demonstrating statistical association to suggest the factors or mechanisms that explain the effects of differing identity choices on preferences and behaviors and their implications for the politics of devolution in Spain.

Chandra and Wilkinson (2008) argue that “activated” identity “guides behavior,” without specifying the mechanism that links identity to behavior (p. 523). We argue here that just because a respondent declares membership in a particular identity category does not necessarily mean that that identity will affect his or her behavior. Abdelal et al. (2009) similarly argue that “just because a person holds a particular identity does not necessarily mean that she will act in a particular way because of it” (p. 3). To link identity to goals and actions, they conceptualize identity as including “social purposes.” They define “social purposes” as “the goals that are shared by members of a group” and argue that groups attach various goals, and thus behaviors, to their identity (pp. 19, 22). They appropriately conclude that this conceptualization of identity makes “a useful contribution to understanding how identities affect the behavior of actors—in other words, the relationship between identity and action” (p. 32). We interpret their discussion as an effort to specify the mechanism(s) that link identities to behaviors.

However, treating “social purposes,” or preferences, as an element of identity itself may introduce a significant problem of endogeneity into any model of the relationship between self-identification and behaviors. That is, without conceptualizing identity and behaviors as distinct, we cannot estimate the effect of one on the other or determine the direction of the relationship between the two. In our analysis, therefore, we argue that identification precedes the formation of preferences and actions. We hypothesize that, in the Spanish context, identification with the AC is primarily the product of attributes of descent and culture, as Chandra and Wilkinson suggest. Because creation of the ACs is associated with the transition from authoritarianism to democracy, we also explore whether the institutional effects of devolution and continuing ideological differences also affect self-identification in Spain. Following the lead of Abdelal et al., we explore whether the link between identity and behavior is to be found in social preferences, operationalized in our analysis as preferences concerning language policies and organization of the state. We then hypothesize that both identities and preferences influence behaviors. We use voting for regionalist and nationalist parties in AC elections, reported in both our 1998 and 2005 data, as indicators of behavior. We focus on voting in AC elections rather than statewide elections because we interpret the former as a more direct expression of orientations toward the AC itself. In this way, we present a logically sound directional argument—that is, that attributes of descent, culture, demographics, and political orientation affect identity; that identity affects preferences; and that both identity and preferences affect behaviors—and we test this argument empirically in the Spanish context. We provide a theoretical argument for why identity affects behavior and find support for this argument in our data.

We base our approach on Chandra and Wilkinson’s conception of “activated” identity. Logically, for a particular identity, on its own, to have an impact on preferences and actions, individuals must affirmatively identify as such. However, demonstrating that individuals declare an identity is not sufficient to explain why that identity might affect behavior. We suggest that strength of attachment is crucial to understanding the relationship between identity and behavior, and especially why nominal identity alone does not necessarily affect behaviors. We argue that strength of attachment to an identity affects the extent to which one wishes to promote and protect that identity. Identity, and especially strength of attachment to that identity, should therefore influence preferences regarding policies that affect attributes, norms, or values associated with that identity, and both identity and preferences should affect behaviors that may advance these policies. This is how we operationalize the argument that identity “guides” behavior.

sec.title: Relevance of Identity
sec.p: Identity is a particularly relevant topic in the Spanish context. Adoption of the decentralized or devolved model of state organization at the moment of transition to democracy in Spain was a direct response to the historical challenge of peripheral nationalisms for state building in Spain (Colomer, 1995; Lecours, 2001; Muro & Quiroga, 2004). The persistence of identification with the ACs, and the political salience of these identities for voting in both regional and statewide elections, has fueled the continuing devolution of competencies from the central government to the governments of the ACs, although devolution has been neither constant over time nor symmetrical across regions (León, 2009; A. P. Montero, 2005).

Recent comparative empirical work suggests devolution weakens identification with the central state (Elkins & Sides, 2007). Spanish scholars have found a similar dynamic in Spain, citing the growth over time in the proportion of survey respondents who self-identify with both Spain and their AC, often defined as “dual identity.” Martínez-Herrera (2002) documents the increase in “dual identity” over the entire democratic period and the corresponding decline in identification exclusively with Spain or the AC, in Spain as a whole and in each of the three “historical” communities. This dynamic is sometimes cited as evidence of increasing support for the Spanish state. It is interpreted as a manifestation of a developing civil or shared identity (Martínez-Herrera, 2002, p. 423; Muro & Quiroga, 2005, p. 24), or as evidence of the decline of exclusivist nationalisms in favor of a multinationalism or pluralism that recognizes other identities but continues to locate sovereignty in the overarching Spanish nation (Balfour & Quiroga, 2007, p. 75; Llera, 2009, p. 326; Núñez, 2001, p. 734). Almost all analyses to date share the perspective adopted by Beramendi and Máiz (2004), who argue that devolution may be considered successful “as long as we observe a robust association between the development of the EA [Estado de las Autonomías, or State of the Autonomies], the expansion of dual identities, and the shrinking of exclusive ones” (p. 138). We make no judgment in this article as to whether further devolution is to be considered evidence of “success” or “failure.” Instead, we focus on the implications of changing patterns of identity, preferences, and voting for the politics of devolution and suggest they predict that more demands for further devolution will be made as identification with the ACs persists.

The data on self-reported identities presented in Table 1, based on six statewide surveys of varying size over the period 1992–2010, make clear that although equal identification with both Spain and one’s AC is growing over time, neither greater nor exclusive identification with one’s own AC is disappearing. This persistence is important for two reasons. First, identification with the AC more than with Spain, or even exclusively with the AC, is not evenly distributed across the regions of Spain. It is not surprising that it is strongest where what Chandra and Wilkinson (2008) refer to as “descent-based attributes” (p. 519), primarily language and culture, differentiate the indigenous or local population from the rest of Spain. These distinctions reinforced the struggle over power and authority between center and periphery in the Spanish state-building process. The Galician (Gallego), Basque, and Catalan linguistic communities were recognized under the short-lived Second Republic as distinct nations and granted significant levels of regional autonomy. Devolution, and definition of the Galician, Basque, and Catalan regions as “historic communities” in the post-Franco democratic constitution, thus represents the continuation of long-standing political differences over definition of the Spanish state. Second, we argue that the persistence of identification with one’s own AC is important because it is associated with significant continuing differences in political preferences with respect to the distribution of power between the center and the ACs in the Spanish state and in behaviors that manifest these preferences, such as voting for regional parties in AC elections. In Table 2, we present the proportions of respondents in each of the five categories of self-declared identity who reported a preference for either greater autonomy or the possibility of independence for the ACs in each of the six statewide surveys reported in Table 1. From these data we see that, compared to the population of Spain as a whole, greater proportions of those who identify with their own AC more than with Spain (“more AC”) also would prefer greater autonomy for the ACs, and large proportions of those who identify exclusively with the AC (“only AC”) would prefer the state to allow the possibility for ACs to become independent. Simple measures of association between these two variables suggest that identities and preferences are not independent of one another. Data available for 1996, 2002, and 2010 (not shown) demonstrate that preferences for a Spanish state that would allow ACs greater autonomy or even independence are strongly associated with preferences for more autonomy or even independence for one’s own AC.

sec.p: Our analysis in this article is designed to move beyond the descriptive data reported in much of the existing literature on Spain and in studies of identity in other ethno-regionally devolved states to clarify the direction of the relationship between identity and behavior. Our study advances the findings in this literature by specifying the mechanism by which identities affect action—that is, through strength of attachment to identity—and the preferences shaped by this attachment.

sec.title: Determinants of Identity
sec.p: Chandra and Wilkinson (2008) differentiate between what they call “nominal” and “activated” identities. They define “nominal” identities as any category for which a person possesses the attributes necessary for membership. An “activated” identity, on the other hand, is an identity in which one professes membership or is assigned membership by others (p. 517). This distinction is an important one, particularly when attempting to determine the relationship between an individual’s identity and his or her preferences and behaviors. If we expect a particular identity to influence an individual’s actions, that individual must actively identify as such. This is not to say simply possessing the attributes necessary to hold an identity has no impact. For example, a person may not self-consciously identify with the culture and values of the group in which he or she was raised, but they are likely to have some influence on that person’s behaviors, and especially on his or her treatment by others. But in such a case it is not the identity that matters but rather the fact of sharing the criteria of descent that define being part of the group. The five-category self-identification scheme most commonly used in Spanish survey research to define respondents’ identity very clearly captures respondents’ “activated” or self-declared identities. The categories of identification are “only with Spain,” “more with Spain than the AC,” “with Spain and the AC equally,” “more with the AC than Spain,” and “only with the AC.”

Chandra and Wilkinson (2008) define an identity as “ethnic” if membership is contingent on attributes of descent while eliminating all other factors from their definition. They acknowledge, however, that this definition is to some extent arbitrary. Most scholars of ethnicity agree that attributes of descent play an important role. However, restricting the definition to these attributes serves only to clarify operationalization of the concept; it has not been shown to be of any analytic value (p. 520). We, too, focus to a large extent on descent, but for two additional methodological and contextual reasons. Scholars of identity often run into problems of endogeneity. For example, in the case of Spain, it may be that knowing the vernacular language increases the likelihood of identifying with the AC or that identifying with the AC might lead a respondent to learn the vernacular language. The descent-based characteristic “mother tongue,” on the other hand, is acquired during early childhood, before one is self-aware enough to choose one’s own identity, and cannot logically or conceptually be the product of identity. Its use as a predictor of identification, instead of “knowledge of the vernacular,” therefore eliminates any problems of endogeneity. Of course, the use of instrumental variables might help us overcome some of the problems of endogeneity, however imperfectly. We do not find this technique necessary, however, because we have a second reason for focusing on attributes of descent. This second reason is contextual. Identification with the AC more than Spain, and exclusively with the AC, is not evenly distributed across the regions of Spain. Rather, it is strongest where descent-based attributes, primarily language and culture, differentiate the indigenous or local population from the rest of Spain. We therefore have good reason to believe that these descent-based attributes are the strongest drivers of primarily or exclusively AC identity.

We expect that respondents born in the AC, and those who descend from parents born in the community, are more likely to identify more, or exclusively, with that community. Similarly, we expect respondents for whom the vernacular language of the AC is their “mother tongue” (the language spoken in their home as a child) to identify more closely with the AC. We also include a measure of religiosity as a predictor of identification, conceived, as Chandra and Wilkinson suggest, as a characteristic of descent: Respondents who attend church at least once a week are coded as “religious.” However, because religiosity may also be an indicator of conservatism in the Spanish context, we expect it not to be strongly associated with identification with the AC and to be associated with identification with Spain instead.

We examine two other categorical factors that may also be conceived as attributes of descent for their effects on self-identification: gender and membership in the “democracy generation,” born after 1958, which reached maturity in the post-Franco period. As we have argued elsewhere (Chernyha & Burg, 2008), membership in the “democracy generation” captures at least some of the institutional effects of devolution and regional autonomy in the post-Franco democratic period. Finally, we also include an indicator of “leftist” ideology in our analysis of the sources of identity (respondents who answer 1–3 on a 10-point, left = 1, right = 10, scale are coded as “leftist”). Although left–right ideology (and religiosity) might also be developed later in life, after one is both aware of oneself, and aware of the (cultural and political) community of which one might be a member, one can make the argument that ideological self-definition occurs concurrently with self-identification and likely captures the element of “choice” integral to the definition of an “activated” identity. Although nationalist and regionalist political movements in Spain are found on both the right and the left of the ideological spectrum and, in some cases, nationalist and regionalist parties of both the left and the right are present in a single region, we nonetheless expect to find that “leftist” ideology increases the likelihood of identification with the AC, whereas conservatism, also captured by our measure of religiosity, leads respondents to identify more closely with Spain.

We conducted a multinomial logistic regression analysis using our 1998 survey data for each of the four ACs with their own indigenous language communities to determine the effects of the descent-based, cultural, political, and demographic attributes described above on respondents’ self-declared identity. We used equal identity (i.e., respondents who identify equally with Spain and the AC) as the reference category, to determine the effects of the independent variables on the likelihood that a respondent identifies either with Spain or with the AC, as opposed to equally with both. The results of these regressions are presented in Table 3.

sec.p: All variables perform, at least directionally, as we hypothesized. Characteristics of native descent, and native mother tongue in particular, reduce the likelihood that a respondent will identify as exclusively Spanish, while increasing the likelihood that a respondent will identify primarily or exclusively with the AC, relative to identifying equally with both, holding all other variables constant. Native mother tongue is statistically significant for almost every category of self-identification in all four regions and has by far the greatest effect on identifying exclusively with the AC. In Galicia, it more than doubles the likelihood of identifying exclusively with the AC rather than equally with both, and in Catalonia it makes exclusive identification 25 times more likely than equal identification. Membership in the “democracy generation,” which reached maturity in the post-Franco period and on which, presumably, the institutional and other changes associated with democratization and devolution have had their strongest effects, does not significantly affect the likelihood of identifying with either Spain or the AC, except in Galicia, where it increases the likelihood of identifying exclusively with the AC. This suggests the institutional effects of devolution are to be found in equal identification (the reference category). Leftist ideology, in contrast, increases the likelihood of identifying mostly or only with the AC. These findings lend support to Chandra and Wilkinson’s contention that identity choice is largely a product of descent-based attributes, including especially native mother tongue, but also suggest the relevance, but lesser impact, of demographic, institutional, and ideological factors.

Understanding identity as a product of descent, culture, demographics, and political orientation allows us to link identity both conceptually and empirically to behavior. Most of these factors logically must precede the process of identification. This leads us to a logically sound directional argument—that attributes of descent, culture, demographics, and political orientation affect self-identification and self-identification affects preferences and behaviors—that we can test empirically.

sec.title: Regional and National Self-Identification
sec.p: Before exploring the impact of identity on preferences and behavior, we examine the relationship between self-identification and how respondents define their AC, that is, whether they view it as a “region,” or as a “nation.” The CIS studies employed here ask respondents, “Which term do you prefer to refer to your autonomous community? Is it a nation or a region?” Preference for the term nation suggests the respondent views the AC as a non-Spanish ethnic nation. As can be seen from Table 4, the degree of self-identification with the AC and perception of the AC as a region or nation are not independent of one another. Large majorities of those who identify equally or more with Spain also perceive the AC as a region, whereas almost half of those who identify more with the AC, and the vast majority of those who identify only with the AC, view it as a nation. About half of those who perceive the AC as a region identify equally with Spain and the AC. But more than 70% of those who view the AC as a nation also identify more or exclusively with it. In effect, attachment to the AC and perception of it as a region or nation may be two dimensions of “activated identity.”

sec.p: We explored this possibility by testing whether the same descent-based, cultural, political, and demographic attributes that affect an individual’s identification with the AC also affect a respondent’s definition of the AC. We ran a binomial logistic regression (not shown), using the same independent variables, with preference for the term nation as the dependent variable and found perceptions of the AC as a nation affected by both characteristics of native descent and leftist ideology. Leftist ideology significantly increases the odds of defining the AC as a nation in all four of the selected ACs. This suggests that perception of the AC, like attachment to the AC, involves an element of choice, and that each constitutes a dimension of “activated identity.” Respondents who identify mostly or exclusively with the AC and prefer the term nation can be said to have a national identity; those who identify mostly or exclusively with the AC but prefer the term region can be said to have a regional identity. To fully understand the impact of identity on preferences and behavior, we argue, it is important to distinguish between regional and national identities. Therefore, we combine preference for the term region or nation with the strength of attachment to the region (or to Spain) to produce a new conceptualization of identity. We explored this approach in our earlier work by developing a different categorical scale of identities (Chernyha & Burg, 2008). We introduce here a further refinement to our conceptualization of identity. We combine those who identify exclusively and primarily with Spain into a single category of activated identity, Spanish. We assign all equal identifiers to their own category of activated identity. Finally, we combine those who identify primarily or exclusively with the AC but then distinguish between those who define the AC as a region and those who define it as a nation. This results in two additional categories of activated identity—regional and national. We also code respondents who self-identified primarily or exclusively with the AC but chose neither or don’t know or did not answer in response to the region or nation question as regional identifiers. Their self-declared identity, which reveals a strong orientation toward the AC, suggests that their activated identity is at least regional, but we cannot assume it is national without an affirmative preference for the term nation. The result is a four category, ordered scale for activated identity that ranges from Spanish to equal, to regional, and to national identity.

We argue that our identity scheme captures not only a respondent’s identity (i.e., as Spanish or of the AC, or both) but also his or her strength of attachment to that identity. A measure of attachment is implicit in the survey question that asks respondents to declare their identity. Rather than asking respondents whether they identify with Spain and their AC, the question asks respondents the extent to which they identify with one relative to the other. Thus, it is logical to assume that those who identify as primarily or exclusively Basque have a stronger attachment to the Basque identity than those who identify as equally Spanish and Basque. Our distinction between regional and national identities further differentiates among those with a strong attachment to the AC. Preference for the term nation indicates a commitment to the cultural characteristics that distinguish the community from the historically Castilian identity of the central Spanish state. National identifiers should be more strongly attached to, and thus more committed to promoting and protecting, the cultural attributes that distinguish their nation from Castilian Spain.

To test whether our new conceptualization does indeed capture the strength of attachment to the AC, we examined responses to the question, “What does Spain mean to you?” As expected, among those with activated Spanish identity, 69.1% define Spain as “my country,” 12.6% as “a nation of which I am a member,” and only 2.4% as “a state formed from various autonomies.” Among those with activated national identity, in contrast, only 5.6% identity Spain as “my country” and only 4.2% as a nation to which they belong, whereas 63.2% identify Spain as a state formed from various autonomies. We also examined responses on an item that asks respondents how “nationalist” they feel with respect to the AC, on a scale ranging from 1 (least nationalist) to 10 (most nationalist). As expected, we found that the strength of nationalist sentiments increases from a mean score of 2.54 for Spanish identifiers to a mean score of 7.55 for national identifiers. Thus, our activated identity scale does capture significant differences in the strength of attachment to the AC.

sec.title: Linking Identity to Preferences and Behavior: Strength of Attachment
sec.p: We argue that strength of attachment to identity is the crucial factor linking identification to behaviors because it affects both the formation of preferences concerning the promotion and protection of that identity and behaviors intended to achieve these goals. Attachment, then, should influence preferences, and both strength of attachment and preferences should affect behaviors, particularly those that may affect the attributes, norms, or values associated with that identity, such as supporting certain public policies and voting. This is how, we argue, identity “guides” behavior.

We examined the relationship between respondents’ activated identities and their self-reported use of the vernacular language in differing social situations as evidence of the “social purposes” Abdelal et al. (2009) suggest are likely to be associated with identity. Ashmore, Deaux, and Mclaughlin-Volpe (2004) argue that language use “is an important form of behavioral involvement” (p. 93) in an ethnic or national identity and indicates the strength of attachment to that identity. We expect, therefore, a strong association between identity and patterns of reported language use across activated identity groups. As can be seen from the data displayed in Table 5, even among those who report knowing the vernacular language, the proportion of respondents using the vernacular increases as identification with the AC increases across a range of public and private situations. These data also suggest that those who identify more with Spain than with the AC (and know the vernacular) are pragmatic about use of the vernacular. Greater proportions of Spanish identifiers use the vernacular in public than in private. This may be an indication that Spanish identity in these ACs is not necessarily an indication of hostility toward the non-Spanish identity groups. These data suggest that language use in private may reflect the strength of attachment to one’s identity but that language use in the public sphere may have as much to do with the requisites of adaption to predominant practice as with attachment to one’s own identity. In both realms, however, patterns of language use confirm that our conceptualization of identity reflects differences in the relative strength of attachment to Spain versus the AC.

sec.title: Testing the Impact of Identity on Preferences and Behavior
sec.p: We have demonstrated that vernacular mother tongue is among the strongest predictors of activated identity and that identity affects patterns of language use. Strong attachment to AC identity should therefore increase the likelihood of favoring policies that promote and protect the vernacular language. Table 6 displays the proportions of each activated identity group that agree with normative statements about use of the local language in the public affairs of the AC (in schools, by public officials, at work, and in public services). These distributions suggest there is a broad consensus across all identity groups that public services in the AC must be offered in both the vernacular and Castilian and substantial agreement across all groups that understanding, if not speaking, the vernacular should be the norm in the workplace. Similarly, there is substantial agreement across all groups, including among Spanish identifiers, that knowledge of the vernacular should be required of public officials in the AC. Significantly, none of these policy principles are entirely exclusionary with respect to identity and its most powerful predictor, native mother tongue. There are great differences, however, with respect to whether language instruction in the schools should be exclusively in the vernacular. This is an exclusionary principle for those who do not know the vernacular or do not know it as well as those for whom it is the mother tongue, that is, for the vast majority of those who identify more with Spain than with the AC. The underlying issue here thus appears to be exclusion, and it is not surprising that much higher proportions of those with activated national identity than of any other identity group should endorse education exclusively in the vernacular.

sec.p: A more detailed picture of the preferences of respondents concerning the language of instruction in the schools is provided by a question that allowed respondents to declare whether they preferred compulsory education to be conducted exclusively in Castilian; mostly in Castilian; half in Castilian, half in the vernacular; mostly in the vernacular; or exclusively in the vernacular. We examine the relative impact of activated identity as well as gender, generation, and ideology as predictors of these preferences. Although “activated identity” incorporates characteristics of descent including mother tongue, it does not take into account current knowledge of the vernacular, regardless of identity or descent. Because we expect those who know the vernacular to be more likely to favor increased instruction in it (or, at least, they will be less likely to support exclusively or primarily Castilian instruction), we include the dichotomous speak vernacular variable (coded 1 if respondents are able to at least speak and understand the language, 0 if they cannot) among the predictors in a multinomial logistic regression analysis of these preferences. We use preference for instruction “half in Castilian, half in the vernacular” as the reference category, as this is the most frequent and least exclusionary preference. The results of this analysis are presented in Table 7. Activated identity is a strong predictor of preferences for language of instruction in compulsory education. Activated Spanish identity greatly increases the likelihood of preferring instruction in Castilian over dual- language instruction. Regional activated identity increases and national identity greatly increases the likelihood of preferring instruction in the vernacular. As expected, knowledge of the vernacular also increases the likelihood of preferring compulsory education in the language and reduces the likelihood of preferring instruction in Castilian. But knowledge of the vernacular language has less of an impact than activated identity (regional or national) on the likelihood of preferring instruction in the vernacular, except in the Basque AC, where the impact of knowing the vernacular greatly increases the likelihood of preferring compulsory school instruction in the vernacular only. These results are consistent with our argument that activated identity shapes preferences on policies that are salient for preservation of identity and in this way “guides” behavior.

sec.p: We therefore expect that identities will also be associated with differences in voting in the AC elections. In particular, we expect regional and national identification to increase the likelihood of voting for a regional, as opposed to statewide, or Spanish, political party. We expect this relationship to hold because, generally speaking, regional parties are more likely than Spanish parties to advance policies that favor the promotion and protection of the AC identity—particularly through demands for greater autonomy and even independence. Of course, voting in regional elections represents an opportunity to pursue various goals, not just those relating to the protection of identity, and these goals may not necessarily complement each other. Individuals may vote differently in regional elections and statewide elections in Spain. Both aggregate voting data and simple cross-tabulations of votes in proximate AC and statewide elections self-reported in Spanish survey data suggest they do. However, strength of attachment should nonetheless be a strong predictor of voting in AC elections. Those with a strong attachment to their AC identity should be more likely to prioritize issues concerning identity over other issues when deciding for which party to cast their vote.

Highly significant (p < .001) chi-square measures of the association between activated identity and party choice in the most recent AC election prior to the 1998 survey suggest that activated ID and voting are not unrelated. But the small sample sizes in each region in the 1998 CIS study, rendered still smaller by the number of respondents who were too young to vote at the time, forgot how they voted, or simply did not answer the question, limit the use of regression techniques to examine the effects of identity on voting in these data. Our task was complicated further by the fact that voting for a nationalist or regionalist party is only an imperfect indicator of autonomist preferences.

The competition model of party behavior suggests that in the presence of competition from a strong regional party in an AC election, statewide parties will seek to increase their electoral appeal by promoting regional interests. This tendency will be magnified in the presence of a well-developed distinctive regional identity (Detterbeck & Renzsch, 2003; Strum, 1999). Examples of this in Spain include the regionalism of statewide parties in Valencia and their advocacy of greater autonomy, effectively marginalizing the regionalist parties, and the advocacy by the Catalan branch of the Spanish Socialist Party of a regionalist agenda, reducing the meaningfulness of the distinction between statewide and regional parties in these ACs (Hopkin, 2009; Roller & Van Houten, 2003; Verge & Barberà, 2009).

Despite these limitations, however, the results of a binary logistic regression on voting in the AC elections preceding the 1998 CIS regional surveys (a vote for any one of the regional parties in each AC was coded 1, and a vote for any of the statewide parties, as well as blank ballots and nonvoting, was coded 0), displayed in Table 8, support the hypothesized relationships among identities, preferences, and voting. Activated national identity is a strong positive predictor of voting for a regional party in all four selected ACs (although not statistically significant in Valencia). Activated Spanish identity, in contrast, reduces the likelihood of such voting in all these ACs (although not statistically significant in the Basque AC). Exclusionary preference for compulsory education in the vernacular is a positive predictor of a regional party vote in all four ACs but is significant only in Catalonia, where it is not as strong a predictor as activated regional or, especially, national identity.

sec.p: To provide a further test of our argument concerning the effects of activated identity on preferences and behavior, we examined data for the four selected ACs from a 2005 CIS study. This is the most recent survey available that allows us to construct our scale of activated identities. The 2005 survey also includes data on the preferences of respondents concerning organization of the Spanish state, that is, their preference for more autonomy, for the possibility of independence for the AC, for continuing the status quo, or even for reestablishing a unitary state. We include preferences for greater autonomy and for the possibility of independence for ACs, defined as manifestations of support for policies that protect or promote regional or national identities, as predictors in a binary logistic regression on voting in the most recent AC elections preceding the 2005 survey. We also include the descent-based characteristics and activated identities employed in the analysis of 1998 data shown in Table 8. We have demonstrated here that descent-based characteristics are strong predictors of activated identity. Similarly, activated identity and preferences for organization of the Spanish state are not independent of one another. In an earlier study, we demonstrated that identity is the strongest predictor of these preferences (Chernyha & Burg, 2008). Nonetheless, VIF scores for our predictors ranged from 1.05 to 1.31 (tolerances from 0.95 to 0.76), well below the threshold for multicollinearity. The results of the 2005 analysis are shown in Table 9.

sec.p: Activated regional and especially national identity significantly increase the likelihood of voting for a regional party in three of the four regions. They also increase the likelihood of a regional vote in Valencia but are not statistically significant. Activated Spanish identity reduces the likelihood of voting for a regional party in all four ACs, significantly so in both the Basque AC and Catalonia. It is not surprising that preference for the possibility of independence for ACs also significantly increases the likelihood of voting for a regional party in these two ACs. In Galicia, however, gender (maleness), membership in the post-Franco generation, and leftist ideology all increase the likelihood of voting for a regional party, but preferences for autonomy or independence are insignificant for voting. These results are consistent with the conceptualization of the effects of activated identity and preferences on behaviors for which we have argued above.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Our findings demonstrate that identification in Spain is largely a product of descent-based attributes, although demographic and ideological factors also have a significant impact on identity choice. Pérez Nievas and Bonet (2006) examined the relationship among identity, preferences, and voting in Catalonia, the Basque Country, and Galicia, based on surveys conducted in these regions in May–June 2004. They found regional identity, preferences for more autonomy or independence, and ideology to be more powerful explanations of regionalist and nationalist voting than demographic factors. Our analysis suggests a sharper distinction between identities and preferences and all other predictors of voting. Our study provides empirical support for the hypothesis advanced by Chandra and Wilkinson and others, as well as in the literature on Spain in particular, that identity guides behavior. Our analysis demonstrates that activated regional and (non-Spanish) national identities increase the likelihood of respondents preferring policies that preserve and promote these identities and voting for regional parties, which not only seek to protect and preserve identities but also advocate for further devolution and, in some cases, even secession. We locate the mechanism that links identity to behavior in an individual’s strength of attachment to his or her identity (i.e., to the AC or Spain) and his or her preferences regarding the attributes, values, and norms associated with that identity, such as exclusionary language policies and increasing the autonomy or even independence of the AC, a finding consistent with the argument of Abdelal et al. (2009) that identities are distinguished by differing “social purposes.” Both identity and preferences affect voting for regional political parties in AC elections, but it is activated identity that has the greatest effect. Finally, our article has implications for the politics of devolution in the Spanish state.

Asymmetry in the powers devolved to the ACs creates incentives for further devolutionary demands. A. P. Montero (2005) reports, for example, that “the unequal distribution of [fiscal] authorities and resources” inherent in asymmetric devolution in Spain leads

disp-quote.p: the have-not regions to up the ante in their calls for new authorities. At the same time, the have regions attempt to protect their special rights. . . . The result is a spiraling of demands for an expansion of subnational authorities and resources that undermines any kind of rational or coherent fiscal logic. (p. 77)

sec.p: Similarly, in a more recent study of negotiations over fiscal decentralization, León (2009, pp. 76, 78, 83) concludes that the asymmetrical character of devolution “has created incentives that make periodic renegotiation of territorial financing . . . rational behavior.” She attributes these incentives to the “asymmetries between the foral regime (applicable in Navarra and the Basque Country) and the common regime of financing (applicable in the 15 other ACs),” to “the disequilibria between the competencies for expenditures and for revenues among the common regime ACs,” and to “the constant redefinition of . . . competencies” itself. She argues that because “generalization of the foral system to the other ACs is not sustainable,” it is “very probable” that “dissatisfaction caused by these differences” will lead to demands for its revision. She concludes that “the predictable evolution of the factors that incentivize periodic renegotiation of the financing system do not permit very optimistic conclusions about the future stability of the system.”

Beramendi and Máiz (2004) have noted the “expansion in the number of regionalist and cryptonationalist parties in AC[s] where they had previously had virtually no political presence” and suggest these parties “pressure incumbents in their ACs to demand that their local region’s autonomous powers match those of the original nationalist ACs” (p. 148). Our findings add an additional dimension to the dynamic of devolution in Spain. Regional and especially national activated identities greatly increase the likelihood of demands for greater devolution or even independence. The persistence in the non-Castilian ACs of Spain of activated regional and (non-Spanish) national identities, and of regional identities in other ACs, because of their effects on preferences and voting behavior, create significant additional incentives for regional political leaderships to press for increased power relative to the center and further devolution of the Spanish state.
